text: In the context of a liquid crystal display, which I think is what we want to talk about today, the liquid crystal material is placed between two substrates, typically glass, and the spacing between those two substrates has to be maintained very precisely. The liquid crystal molecules basically respond to an electric field, and it's important that the response be the same over the entire area of the display, so whether it's a laptop computer or a cell phone or a television set, this-- to maintain uniformity of the image, we have to have very strict uniformity of the spacing between the top and bottom substrates. For many years the spacing was accomplished with little spheres, so basically-- it is actually correct to say that basically these little spheres were put down like from a salt shaker.  They were randomly placed. So the little spheres would simply scatter, and they cover perhaps less than one percent of the area, but they were precise little glass or plastic balls precisely dimensioned, typically in the range of three to five microns, and that provided that uniformity of spacing. More recently, over probably about the last ten years, these little round spacers have been replaced by little columns that set the spacing, and they're typically hidden behind the black matrix. The column, the spacing, is very important and very crucial to the operation of the display because it has to be very tightly controlled.
